synsets.definition: Complete lack of interest, enthusiasm, or concern toward stimuli or experiences
Chinese Taoist concept of natural action without forcing or striving; state of flowing with circumstances without preference
Buddhist concept of mental calmness and composure, especially as maintained in difficult situations without attachment to outcomes
Arabic concept of patient endurance and acceptance without emotional reaction to circumstances
Calm indifference or lack of concern; relaxed and casual attitude toward events or stimuli
Greek philosophical concept of things that are morally indifferent; matters neither good nor bad in themselves
Persian Sufi concept of detachment from worldly concerns and material preferences
Japanese Zen concept of nothingness or emptiness; state of mind free from preferences and judgments
Southern African philosophical concept applied to collective emotional neutrality and balanced community response
French-derived state of being unimpressed or indifferent due to overexposure or sophistication
Sanskrit term for an unmodified, changeless state of consciousness without emotional fluctuation
Japanese aesthetic concept of finding beauty in solitude and accepting things as they are without preference
Arabic-Islamic concept of accepting outcomes with indifference to personal preference, surrendering to divine will
French philosophical concept of disinterested judgment; aesthetic or moral neutrality free from personal stake
Greek-derived state of suspended will or choice; neutrality arising from inability to form preferences
German mystical concept of letting go and allowing things to be without interference or preference
Japanese aesthetic of finding contentment in simple, humble things without striving for more
Sanskrit Buddhist concept of the middle way; avoiding extremes of preference and aversion
Arabic Islamic virtue of patient perseverance and emotional steadiness in face of adversity
Medieval Latin concept of spiritual apathy or indifference; lack of care for spiritual or worldly matters
Korean cultural concept of modest, unassuming behavior that avoids expressing strong preferences publicly
Greek Stoic and Epicurean ideal of tranquil indifference; freedom from emotional disturbance
Sanskrit yogic principle of contentment; satisfaction with present circumstances without craving change
Contemporary expression of mild indifference or lack of enthusiasm; unemotional response to stimuli
Japanese Zen experience of seeing one's true nature; state of awakened consciousness beyond preferences
